articles.headline: Fact or Fiction? In This War, It Is Hard to Tell.
articles.snippet: Social media is full of false and misleading posts. The rise in A.I. is making it worse. And the trust in traditional news sources has declined.
articles.abstract: Social media is full of false and misleading posts. The rise in A.I. is making it worse. And the trust in traditional news sources has declined.
articles.lead_paragraph: The major social media platforms, once heralded for their ability to document global events in real time, face a crisis of authenticity — one of their own making, critics say.

articles.headline: The Secrets Hamas Knew About Israel’s Military
articles.snippet: Hamas gunmen surged into Israel in a highly organized and meticulously planned operation that suggested a deep understanding of Israel’s weaknesses. Here is how the attacks unfolded.
articles.abstract: Hamas gunmen surged into Israel in a highly organized and meticulously planned operation that suggested a deep understanding of Israel’s weaknesses. Here is how the attacks unfolded.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 10 gunmen from Gaza knew exactly how to find the Israeli intelligence hub — and how to get inside.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Israel Sticks to Call for Gaza Evacuation and Readies a Possible Invasion
articles.snippet: The United Nations and others condemned the call for more than a million people to leave northern Gaza, and Israel softened its initial 24-hour timetable.
articles.abstract: The United Nations and others condemned the call for more than a million people to leave northern Gaza, and Israel softened its initial 24-hour timetable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel called for the evacuation of more than a million citizens from the northern Gaza Strip and concentrated more armed forces around the enclave on Friday, signaling that it may be preparing to escalate the war with Hamas.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Farnaz Fassihi, Edward Wong and Victoria Kim

articles.headline: Inside Trump’s Backroom Effort to Lock Up the Nomination
articles.snippet: As the former president dodges debates, it can seem as if he’s bypassing the primary. But he and his team have been working quietly to twist the delegate rules in their favor.
articles.abstract: As the former president dodges debates, it can seem as if he’s bypassing the primary. But he and his team have been working quietly to twist the delegate rules in their favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long after the new chairman of the Republican Party in Hawaii was elected in May, he received a voicemail from none other than Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Israeli Invasion Plans Target Gaza City and Hamas Leadership
articles.snippet: The goal, according to three senior officers, is to wipe out the top political and military hierarchy of Hamas, the Palestinian group that controls Gaza.
articles.abstract: The goal, according to three senior officers, is to wipe out the top political and military hierarchy of Hamas, the Palestinian group that controls Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military is preparing to invade the Gaza Strip soon with tens of thousands of soldiers ordered to capture Gaza City and destroy the enclave’s current leadership, according to three senior Israeli military officers who outlined unclassified details about the plan.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Goodwill Tries to Figure Out Online Commerce
articles.snippet: The nonprofit retailer helps provide jobs and training to those in need. But it needs revenue from online sales to help fund its charitable aims.
articles.abstract: The nonprofit retailer helps provide jobs and training to those in need. But it needs revenue from online sales to help fund its charitable aims.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goodwill knows it needs to figure out e-commerce. At stake, the nonprofit retailer says, is its ability to generate enough revenue to fulfill its mission: providing job opportunities for those in need.

articles.headline: Nikki Haley’s Past Stance on Israel Could Be Key to Her Campaign’s Future
articles.snippet: The G.O.P. contender’s combative defense of Israel defined her tenure at the United Nations. Will it also define her presidential campaign?
articles.abstract: The G.O.P. contender’s combative defense of Israel defined her tenure at the United Nations. Will it also define her presidential campaign?
articles.lead_paragraph: In January 2017, Danny Danon, Israel’s ambassador to the United Nations, received a phone call from Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina and Donald Trump’s newly appointed ambassador to the United Nations.

articles.headline: How a Fertilizer Shortage Is Spreading Desperate Hunger
articles.snippet: Across Africa and in parts of Asia, disruption to the supply chain for fertilizer is raising food prices and increasing malnutrition.
articles.abstract: Across Africa and in parts of Asia, disruption to the supply chain for fertilizer is raising food prices and increasing malnutrition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suleiman Chubado is not entirely clear what caused the price of fertilizer to more than double over the past year, but he is bitterly aware of the consequences. At his farm in northeastern Nigeria, he can no longer afford enough fertilizer, so his corn is stunted and pale, the scraggly plants bending toward the powdery earth.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Finbarr O'Reilly For The New York Times

articles.headline: ‘I Want to Be Forgiven. I Just Want to Be Forgiven.’
articles.snippet: When the Minnesota Board of Pardons meets, supplicants have 10 minutes to make the case for mercy.
articles.abstract: When the Minnesota Board of Pardons meets, supplicants have 10 minutes to make the case for mercy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The supplicants clustered outside the enormous closed doors. They paced the hallway, fidgeted on benches, knitted their hands and waited, waited, for their 10-minute chance at mercy.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry and Photographs By Todd Heisler

articles.headline: Slaughter at a Festival of Peace and Love Leaves Israel Transformed
articles.snippet: In this massacre of its youth, Israel’s 75-year-old quest for some carefree normalcy met the murderous fury of those long-oppressed Palestinians who deny the state’s right to exist.
articles.abstract: In this massacre of its youth, Israel’s 75-year-old quest for some carefree normalcy met the murderous fury of those long-oppressed Palestinians who deny the state’s right to exist.
articles.lead_paragraph: At daybreak, Hila Fakliro looked up to the sky from the vodka and Red Bull cocktails she was mixing: “Oh, my God,” she said. “Look! There are fireworks!”
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen, Sergey Ponomarev and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv

articles.headline: Gaza’s Hospitals Face ‘Impossible’ Choices With Israel Evacuation Order
articles.snippet: As a widely anticipated ground invasion looms, hospitals in Gaza City said they had no way to evacuate thousands of sick and injured patients.
articles.abstract: As a widely anticipated ground invasion looms, hospitals in Gaza City said they had no way to evacuate thousands of sick and injured patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people injured in Israeli airstrikes are streaming into hospitals in Gaza, transported by overfilled ambulances and sharing bloodied gurneys at the entrances. Workers and bystanders rush to carry the victims inside, where only the most critically wounded are allowed to stay, and the rest are sent home.

articles.headline: As Israeli Invasion Looms, Diplomats Seek to Meet Gaza’s Dire Human Needs
articles.snippet: The U.S., Egypt and other countries are urging the delivery of food, water and fuel to counter the desperate shortages facing Gaza’s two million residents.
articles.abstract: The U.S., Egypt and other countries are urging the delivery of food, water and fuel to counter the desperate shortages facing Gaza’s two million residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Diplomats were locked in frantic talks on Sunday to ease the humanitarian crisis in Gaza as an Israeli ground invasion appeared imminent.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Aaron Boxerman and Raja Abdulrahim

articles.headline: Rite Aid, Facing Slumping Sales and Opioid Suits, Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The pharmacy chain, one of the country’s largest, faces more than a thousand lawsuits that say it filled illegal prescriptions for painkillers.
articles.abstract: The pharmacy chain, one of the country’s largest, faces more than a thousand lawsuits that say it filled illegal prescriptions for painkillers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rite Aid, one of the largest pharmacy chains in the United States, filed for bankruptcy on Sunday, weighed down by billions of dollars in debt, declining sales and more than a thousand federal, state and local lawsuits claiming it filled thousands of illegal prescriptions for painkillers.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: China Got a Big Contract. Nepal Got Debt and a Pricey Airport.
articles.snippet: China called the project a “signature” of its cooperation with Nepal. Insiders and documents reveal the pitfalls of China’s infrastructure-at-any-cost model.
articles.abstract: China called the project a “signature” of its cooperation with Nepal. Insiders and documents reveal the pitfalls of China’s infrastructure-at-any-cost model.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a sweltering June morning, the new international terminal at the airport in Pokhara, Nepal’s second-biggest city, roared to life with the arrival of a Sichuan Airlines flight from China.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Bhadra Sharma and Claire Fu

articles.headline: How ‘A.I. Agents’ That Roam the Internet Could One Day Replace Workers
articles.snippet: Researchers are transforming chatbots into online agents that play games, query websites, schedule meetings, build bar charts and do more.
articles.abstract: Researchers are transforming chatbots into online agents that play games, query websites, schedule meetings, build bar charts and do more.
articles.lead_paragraph: The widely used chatbot ChatGPT was designed to generate digital text, everything from poetry to term papers to computer programs. But when a team of artificial intelligence researchers at the computer chip company Nvidia got their hands on the chatbot’s underlying technology, they realized it could do a lot more.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Karen Weise

articles.headline: For Hostages’ Families, an ‘Endless Loop of Hope and Despair’
articles.snippet: Relatives of those captured or missing express despair at the lack of information, and they are terrified of what an expected Israeli invasion of Gaza may mean for their loved ones.
articles.abstract: Relatives of those captured or missing express despair at the lack of information, and they are terrified of what an expected Israeli invasion of Gaza may mean for their loved ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yakov Argamani has the pale face and broken soul of a man whose child is in extreme danger. He shuffles around his immaculate house in southern Israel, a book of psalms in his right hand, the front door constantly banging open and shut with visitors, plates of freshly made food, more than he could ever possibly eat, piling up on the countertops.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Tamir Kalifa

articles.headline: China Bet It All on Real Estate. Now Its Economy Is Paying the Price.
articles.snippet: After relying on a borrow-to-build model for decades, Beijing must make difficult choices about the country’s housing market and economic future.
articles.abstract: After relying on a borrow-to-build model for decades, Beijing must make difficult choices about the country’s housing market and economic future.
articles.lead_paragraph: When China’s housing boom seemed like a one-way bet, Gary Meng’s parents bought an apartment from China Evergrande, the country’s biggest developer. Soon the company called with another pitch: to manage their wealth.
